For the hotter melting metals, they probably didn't explode the ice because they were hot enough to cause a Leidenfrost effect due to the higher temperature differential. This would mean that the molten metals have less contact with the ice, causing less of it to vaporize, while also allowing any vapor that did form to slip around the molten mass. This would mean the pressure was self regulating, and so no compression was ever reached, which is required for such violent explosions.

I believe that the difference between what different metals (or other materials) put on the ice is due to their ability to have heat removed from them quickly...a mathematical rate.  For example, one of the main reasons that aluminum is used for car radiators is that heat can be removed from them rather quickly by air flowing over them.  In the ice, that quickness to have heat removed would mean that the heat is applied to the ice quicker as well. If the material is slow at shedding off its heat, when exposed to ice, it would make the ice melt more slowly, then turn to steam more slowly as well...where as a material that can shed its heat quickly will melt the ice quicker, then turn it to steam quicker, causing more pressure in the ice, causing it to explode.

The other metals have a higher melting point, so the leidenfrost effect effect comes into play. When you pour them into the ice, they dont actually touch the ice, they are too hot, causing a barrier of steam, allowing it to cool slowly and form a plug. Lead and other metals with a lower melting point make contact with the ice, transferring heat, causing extreme stress on the ice (like pouring cold water into a hot glass and it cracking).

I think the different reactions given by different metals is because of different reactivities. Al and Pb being more reactive than hydrogen displace get oxidised, reducing the H+ in water to hydrogen gas. The gas produced has to go somewhere so it pushes though the ice, and hence breaking it. Cu is less reactive than hydrogen (and brass, majorly consisting of Cu) doesn't produce hydrogen gas and thus no explosion.(Though brass reacts a little differently as it also contains Zn which is more reactive than hydrogen thus there is some production of gas but the increase in pressure(due to the increased volume) is not enough to break the ice and the gas just exits from the top spurting metal with it. So if you want to see explosions you should use the metals higher in the rectivity series. (Though this is just my hypothesis)

Could It have something to do with expansion and contraction? My guess is the rapid temperature change is so sudden that the metal starts to expand near instantly. A similar thing happens (only thousands of years slower) when water gets in the cracks of a rock and freezes. The rock eventually gets pushed apart from the inside. They've had cases with rocks practically exploding from this same phenomenon. If the block of ice were the right shape, it theoretically wouldn't shatter. The structural integrity might be so strong (let's say in a sphere), that the ice would end up becoming a mold. This might explain why the bottom piece of ice is a diamond. The weak points in the ice must have either been directly in between the corners, or on the corners themselves. This concept of expansion and contraction might help explain why it works best with metal that has a low melting point. With brass and copper, it takes more to cool them down. They're so hot that the ice can't exchange energy fast enough to make them rapidly expand. While with lead and aluminium, the low temperatures allows less energy to induce a change. If you were to try the same experiment with brass and a large block of dry ice, you might get the explosion you're looking for.

The reason why the aluminum and lead ezploded the ice and not the copper is because of their Specific Heat Compacity (S.H.C). Becuase lead and aluminum have lower S.H.C. it lose a lot more heat. And the more heat they lose, the more heat the block of ice gains causing it to vaporise into water vapour.

Now because the molten aluminum had being cooling down, it turns solid, trapping the water vapour allowing it to build up pressure. And eventually, the water vapour bust out from where ever it can( aka : exploding the ice to a million pieces).

What it looks like to me is the higher the melting point, the less reactive it is to thermal shock. With copper, the immediate cooling doesn't allow it time to be reactive. With Lead, that's the most reactive explosion we've had yet I think. So I think that we can accurately predict how reactive the molten metals will be based on how hot the metal needs to be to become a liquid
